description: From Middle English pultrie, from Old French pouleterie, from poulet, diminutive of poule (“hen”), from Latin pullus (“chick”).
For the development of Middle English /u/ to modern /oʊ/, /əʊ/ before /lt/, /ld/, /ln/, compare boult, boulder, colter/coulter, poultice, shoulder, won't.

entries.meaning: Domestic fowl (e.g. chickens, ducks, turkeys, and geese) raised for food (either meat or eggs).
The meat from a domestic fowl.
